DT Article
TI An illustrated synopsis and keys to afrotropical genera of the epifamily
   Dolichopodoidae (Diptera: Empidoidea).
AU Grichanov, Igor Ya. (grichanov@mail.ru) 
SO Priamus
SU Supplement 24
PS 1-99
PD 16 September 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB An illustrated synopsis and keys to afrotropical genera of the epifamily
   Dolichopodoidae (Diptera: Empidoidea). - Priamus Supplement 24: 1-98,
   305 figs. The use of the epifamily rank Dolichopodoidae (type genus
   Dolichopus Latreille, 1796) is proposed for the Dolichopodidae s. lat.,
   incorporating paraphyletic families Dolichopodidae and Microphoridae and
   subfamily Parathalassiinae incertae sedis that shares features of both
   Dolichopodidae and Microphoridae. Additionally, the use of the epifamily
   rank Empidoidae (type genus Empis Linnaeus, 1758) is proposed for the
   rest families of the superfamily Empidoidea. A brief synopsis of 84
   genera of Dolichopodidae s.s. and 3 genera of Microphoridae and
   Parathalassiinae is given along with illustration of habitus of some
   typical and rare afrotropical species. Revised keys to afrotropical
   genera of the family Dolichopodidae (Diptera) are compiled. Illustration
   of typical characters of most afrotropical genera is given. Dactylonotus
   meuffelsi Grichanov, 1998, is placed in synonymy to D. rudebecki
   Vanschuytbroeck, 1960 (syn. nov.). The following recombinations are also
   proposed: Amblypsilopus prysjonesi (Meuffels et Grootaert, 2007), comb.
   nov., Bickeliolus gerlachi (Meuffels et Grootaert, 2007), comb. nov.,
   Lichtwardtia melanesiana (Bickel, 2008), comb. nov. The genus Machaerium
   Haliday, 1832 is recorded from the Afrotropics for the first time.
C1 Grichanov, Igor Ya.; All-Russian Institute of Plant Protection
   Podbelskogo 3, 196608 St.Petersburg-Pushkin, Russia, Russia.
EM grichanov@mail.ru
SC Zoology
SN 1015-8243

   Taxonomic position; Key; Land zones

DT Article
TI Revision of Epyris afer (Magretti, 1884), comb. rev. (Hymenoptera:
   Bethylidae) with new synonymy and description of two new species.
AU Stein, Paulo R.W. (steinprw@gmail.com) 
   Alencar, Isabel D.C.C.
   Barbosa, Diego N.
   Azevedo, Celso O.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3032
PS 17-32
PD 16 Sep 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3032.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt03032p032.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Pristocera afra Magretti, 1884 which currently belongs to genus Epyris
   Westwood is revised and redescribed. The lectotype of P. afra Magretti
   is designated. New synonymy is proposed for Epyris afer (Magretti,
   1884): Epyris pilosipes Kieffer, 1904, syn. nov.; Epyris analis Kieffer,
   1905, syn. nov.; Epyris secundus Brues, 1906, syn. nov.; Epyris
   rugicollis Cameron, 1906, syn. nov.; Epyris plurilineata Turner, 1928,
   syn. nov. Two new species Epyris enerterus Stein & Azevedo, sp. nov.
   (Myanmar) and Epyris penatii Stein & Azevedo, sp. nov. (Sudan) are
   described and illustrated. Epyris afer (Magretti) is newly recorded from
   Yemen, United Arab Emirates, Thailand, and Vietnam.
C1 Stein, Paulo R.W.; Universidade Federal do Espirito Santo, Departamento
   de Biologia, Av. Marechal Campos 1468, Maruipe, 29.040-090 Vitoria ES,
   Brazil, Brazil.
EM steinprw@gmail.com
SC Zoology

   Combination revalidated, Transferred back from Disepyris, p. 18; Syn

DT Article
TI The Little Lichen Dragon - an extraordinary katydid from the Ecuadorian
   Andes (Orthoptera, Tettigoniidae, Phaneropterinae, Dysoniini).
AU Braun, Holger (braun@fcnym.unlp.edu.ar) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3032
PS 33-39
PD 16 Sep 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3032.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt03032p039.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Lichenodraculus matti gen. et sp. nov. is described, along with its
   conspicuous diurnal calling song and some aspects of its interesting
   ecology and life history. The song allowed a complete acoustic
   assessment of the altitudinal distribution of this otherwise very
   cryptic canopy-dwelling insect. The nymph perfectly mimics epiphytic
   lichens growing in the same elevation range, and apparently the downside
   of this camouflage is a strictly lichenous diet.
C1 Braun, Holger; Division Entomologia, Museo de La Plata, Paseo del Bosque
   s/No, 1900 La Plata, Argentina, Argentina.
EM braun@fcnym.unlp.edu.ar
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America

   Lichenodraculus matti, p. 34]. 
   Lichenodraculus matti (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Ecuador, P. 34].

DT Article
TI Reinstatement of the genus Capicua Navas with descriptions of two new
   species (Neuroptera, Myrmeleontidae).
AU Michel, Bruno (bruno.michel@cirad.fr) 
   Akoudjin, Massouroudini
SO Zootaxa
VL 3032
PS 40-46
PD 16 Sep 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3032.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt03032p046.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The genus Capicua Navas, 1921, synonymised with Geyria Esben-Petersen,
   1920 by Stange (2004), is reinstated and redescribed. The unique
   specimen of Capicua fulvicauda Navas, 1921 kept in the Museum d'Histoire
   Naturelle, Paris is designated as lectotype. Two new species of antlions
   from West Africa are described and tentatively included in Capicua
   pending more material of the type species C. fulvicauda to verify this
   placement. Holotypes and paratypes are deposited in the collection of
   CIRAD/CBGP in Montpellier, France.
C1 Michel, Bruno; CIRAD, UMR CBGP (INRA/IRD/CIRAD/Montpellier SupAgro),
   Campus International de Baillarguet, CS 30016, 34988
   Montferrier-sur-Lez, France, France.
EM bruno.michel@cirad.fr
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Description;
   Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Land zones;
   Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Capicua acalcarata; Capicua nigra [Burkina /  / New species] [Mali /  /
   ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Neuroptera
OR Capicua - Navas 1921 (Neuroptera): [Removal from synonymy, With Geyria
   Esben-Petersen 1920, p. 41]. 
   Capicua acalcarata (Neuroptera): [Sp nov, Mali, P. 44]. 
   Capicua fulvicauda - Navas 1921 (Neuroptera): [Lectotype designated, P.
   41; Redescription, P. 41; Combination revalidated, Transferred back from
   Geyria, p. 41]. 
   Capicua nigra (Neuroptera): [Sp nov, Mali, P. 42]. 
   Geyria - Esben-Petersen 1920 (Neuroptera): [Removal from synonymy,
   Capicua Navas 1921, p. 41]. 
   Geyria fulvicauda - (Navas 1921) (Neuroptera): [Referred to, Capicua, p.
   41].

PT J
AN ZOOR14712082424
DT Article
TI Revision and phylogeny of the rare Priotomis Townes (Hymenoptera,
   Ichneumonidae, Cryptinae), with three new species and first description
   of the male.
AU Tedesco, Anazelia M.
   Aguiar, Alexandre P. (aguiar.2@osu.edu.) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3031
PS 14-36
PD 16 Sep 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3031.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt03031p036.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Priotomis vinhai Tedesco, sp. nov., from the restingas of southeastern
   Brazil, P. echyrus Tedesco, sp. nov., from Mexico and Costa Rica, and
   Priotomis flammatus Tedesco, sp. nov., from Panama and Brazil, are
   described and illustrated. The monophyly of the genus and the
   relationships of its species were cladistically tested using implied
   weighting, in a matrix with 22 species, including four species of
   Priotomis, and 92 external structural characters. Concavity constants
   (K) from 1 to 6 were tested. All analyses recovered Priotomis as
   monophyletic. A redescription of Priotomis is presented, combining the
   original definition with original information, expanding the limits of
   the genus. All results indicate P. vinhai, sp. nov. as the basal-most
   species of the genus; all results with K=2[long dash]5 recovered the
   apical clade P. rana + (P. echyrus, sp. nov. + P. flammatus, sp. nov.).
   An updated key to species is presented. Additional distribution records
   are provided, expanding the known range of Priotomis to 41[degrees]11'
   latitude degrees, from Mexico to Argentina.
C1 Aguiar, Alexandre P.; Universidade Federal do Espirito Santo, Depto de
   Ciencias Biologicas, Av. Fernando Ferrari, s/n, Goiabeiras, Vitoria, ES
   29075[long dash]010, Brazil, Brazil.
EM aguiar.2@osu.edu.
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   Evolution; Land zones; Nearctic region; Neotropical region; North
   America; Central America; South America
DE Priotomis [Phylogeny /  / New record; systematics] [Mexico /  /
   distribution] [Central America /  / ] [South America /  / ]. 
   Priotomis echyrus [Mexico /  / New species] [Costa Rica /  / ]. 
   Priotomis flammatus [Panama /  / New species] [Brazil /  / ]. 
   Priotomis vinhai [Brazil /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Terebrantia,
   Ichneumonoidea, Ichneumonidae

   Redescription, P. 19; Key to species, P. 20; New record]. 
   Priotomis echyrus - Tedesco 2011 (Ichneumonidae): [Sp nov, Mexico, Host
   unknown, p. 26].

DT Article
TI Parakari a New Genus of the Family Baetidae (Insecta: Ephemeroptera)
   from Guyana Highlands.
AU Nieto, Carolina (macarolina_nieto@yahoo.com.ar) 
   Derka, Tomas
SO Zootaxa
VL 3032
PS 47-59
PD 16 Sep 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3032.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt03032p059.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Baetidae is one of the most diverse families of Ephemeroptera. In South
   America this family now encompasses 27 genera and more than 130 species.
   The Guyana region is known for its extraordinary diversity and high
   level of endemism, which is, above all, remarkable at the tops of the
   isolated flat-topped table mountains [long dash] tepuis. Recently
   various international speleological expeditions to Churi-tepui explored
   the cave systems of this mountain. Here we describe a new genus of
   Baetidae recently found during the mentioned expeditions to Churi-tepui
   and Auyan-tepui. Parakari n. gen. can be distinguish from the other
   genera of this family, among other characters, in the nymphs by the
   absence of abdominal gills I, tarsal claws with subapical denticle
   larger than the others, right mandible with prostheca bifid and
   pectinate and with incisors positioned in obtuse angle to mola area,
   lingua with a tuft of setae, segment II of maxillary palpi with a
   concavity and a hole apically and segment II of labial palpi with a
   strong distomedial projection. In the adults the hind wings are absent
   and genitalia with segment II of forceps with a constriction, segment
   III elongate and long. Two new species are included in this genus; each
   one was collected at different tepui. A key and illustrations are
   included.
C1 Nieto, Carolina; CONICET-Instituto de Biodiversidad Neotropical,
   Facultad de Ciencias Naturales e IML, Miguel Lillo 251, Tucuman, UNASUR
   (4000), Argentina, Argentina.
EM macarolina_nieto@yahoo.com.ar
RI Nieto, Carolina/AAX-6877-2020
OI Nieto, Carolina/0000-0003-1909-1750
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; South America
DE Baetidae [South America /  / Key to genera]. 
   Parakari auyanensis; Parakari churiensis [Venezuela /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Ephemeroptera
OR Baetidae (Ephemeroptera): [Key to genera, South America, Nymphs,
   additional couplets, p. 49]. 
   Parakari (Ephemeroptera): [Gen nov, Of family Baetidae, Type species
   Parakari churiensis, p. 48; Key to species, Nymphs, p. 49]. 
   Parakari auyanensis (Ephemeroptera): [Sp nov, Venezuela, P. 50]. 
   Parakari churiensis (Ephemeroptera): [Sp nov, Venezuela, P. 52]. 
DI 10.11646/zootaxa.3032.1.5

DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI A review of the Hangingflies (Mecoptera: Bittacidae) of South Asia with
   the description of a new species of Bittacus from Nepal.
AU Bicha, Wesley J. (mecoptera@live.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3032
PS 60-64
PD 16 Sep 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3032.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt03032p064.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of hangingfly, Bittacus coheri, is described from the
   eastern Terai of Nepal. The male of this species differs from all other
   known south Asian hangingflies by the presence of a bifurcated flap-like
   structure between the male epiandrial lobes of tergum 9. Bittacus
   taraienseis Penny is placed in synonymy with B. indicus Walker, leaving
   south Asia (Iran to Bangladesh) with six species of hangingflies: at
   least two with West African affinities and at least two with oriental
   affinities. Additional records of B. nodosus and B. henryi are given.
C1 Bicha, Wesley J.; 121 Old Batley Road, Oliver Springs, TN 37840, USA,
   USA.
EM mecoptera@live.com
SC Zoology; Developmental Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Life cycle and
   development; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Bittacus coheri [Nepal /  / New species]. 
   Bittacus henryi [Sri Lanka /  / Distribution]. 
   Bittacus nodosus [Life cycle / Flight period / Presumed extension
   record; male]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Mecoptera
OR Bittacus coheri (Mecoptera): [Sp nov, Nepal, P. 60]. 
   Bittacus henryi (Mecoptera). 
   Bittacus indicus - Walker 1853 (Mecoptera): [Syn nov, Bittacus
   taraiensis Penny 1969, p. 63]. 
   Bittacus nodosus (Mecoptera). 
DI 10.11646/zootaxa.3032.1.6

DT Article
TI A revision of the genus Stictobura Crotch and description of a new
   species of Sticholotis Crotch (Coleoptera: Coccinellidae:
   Sticholotidinae).
AU Poorani, J. (pooranij@gmail.com) 
   Vandenberg, Natalia J.
   Booth, R.G.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3031
PS 1-13
PD 16 Sep 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3031.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt03031p013.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The species of Stictobura Crotch (1874) (Coccinellidae: Sticholotidinae)
   are revised. Stictobura gibbula (Weise, 1908) indeed belongs to
   Sticholotis Crotch (1874) under which it was originally described (stat.
   rev.) and is removed from Stictobura. Stictobura buruensis Korschefsky
   (1944) is transferred to Sticholotis (new combination). Lectotypes are
   designated for Sticholotis (Apterolotis) andrewesi Weise (1908),
   Sticholotis (Apterolotis) gibbula Weise (1908), Stictobura semipolita
   Sicard (1911), and Stictobura rubroguttata Sicard (1925). The species of
   Stictobura are keyed and notes on biology are provided wherever
   available. Sticholotis magnostriata sp. n., which is externally similar
   to the species of Stictobura, is described from India (Assam).

   Karnataka, India, India.

   revalidated, Transferred back from Stictobura, p. 8].

   (Coleoptera: Myxophaga: Torridincolidae).

LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The adults and larvae of a new species of Torridincolidae, Iapir
   quadridentatus sp. nov., are described from Pernambuco State, Brazil.
   This represents the first record of the family from Northeast Brazil.
   Larvae and adults were found on submerged leaves of Mourera sp.
   (Podostemaceae).

TI Notes on winter flies Trichoceridae (Diptera) of Mongolia with
   description of new species.
AU Petrasiunas, Andrius (Andrius.Petrasiunas@gf.vu.lt) 
   Podenas, Sigitas
SO Zootaxa
VL 3031
PS 61-68
PD 16 Sep 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3031.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt03031p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The family of winter flies Trichoceridae is newly recorded for Mongolia.
   Four species, Trichocera (Metatrichocera) gigantea (Dahl), T. (M.)
   mackenziei (Dahl), T. (Saltrichocera) regelationis (Linnaeus) and T.
   (Trichocera) hiemalis (De Geer) are first recorded in Mongolia from
   sampling during 1996, 2003[long dash]2006, 2008. A new species,
   Trichocera (Saltrichocera) chuluuta, is described from specimens
   collected during the fieldwork of the Mongolian Aquatic Insect Survey
   Project in western and north-central Mongolia.

DT Article
TI A revision of Gasteruption Latreille (Hymenoptera: Gasteruptiidae) in
   the Neotropical Region.
AU Macedo, Antonio Carlos Cruz (accmacedo2003@yahoo.com.br) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3030
PS 1-62
PD 16 Sep 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt03030p062.pdf
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt03030p062.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The Neotropical species of Gasteruption Latreille are revised,
   described, diagnosed, and illustrated; a key for females is provided.
   Twenty six valid species are recognized, thirteen of which are described
   as new: G. amputatum Townes, G. barn- stoni (Westwood), G. bertae n.
   sp., G. bispinosum Kieffer, G. brachychaetum Schrottky, G. brandaoi n.
   sp., G. brasiliense (Blanchard), G. floridanum (Bradley), G. glauciae n.
   sp., G. guildingi (Westwood), G. hansoni n. sp., G. helenae n. sp., G.
   huberi n. sp., G. kaweahense (Bradley), G. lianae n. sp., G. loiaconoae
   n. sp., G. masneri n. sp., G. oliveirai n. sp., G. parvum Schrottky, G.
   rafaeli n. sp., G. sartor Schletterer, G. smithi n. sp., G. tenue
   Kieffer, G. townesi (Alayo), G. visaliae (Bradley), and G. wahli n. sp.
   The following new synonymies are proposed: G. maculicorne Cameron, G.
   macroderum Schletterer, and G. zapotecum Schletterer with G. barnstoni;
   G. bihamatum Kieffer, G. fallens Kieffer, G. fiebrigi Schrottky, G.
   leptodomum Kieffer, G. montivagum Kieffer, and G. strandi Kieffer with
   G. bispinosum; G. annulitarse Schrottky, G. brasiliae Kieffer, G.
   gracillimum (Schletterer), G. longicauda Kieffer, G. petroselini
   Schrottky, G. subtropicale Schrottky and G. torridum (Bradley) with G.
   brasiliense; G. rufipectus (Westwood) with G. guildingi; G. angustatum
   (Kieffer) with G. kaweahense; G. horni Brethes with G. parvum. The
   following taxa are considered as species inquirendae: G. albitarse
   Schletterer, G. austini Jennings and Smith, G. subcoriaceum Kieffer n.
   stat., and G. tenuicolle Schletterer. As well, G ru- brum Taschenberg is
   synonymized with Pseudofoenus infumatus (Schletterer). In addition, G.
   tenue Pasteels, 1957a from Australia is a junior homonym of G. tenue
   Kieffer, 1922 and is renamed G. pasteelsi n. name.

   Brazil.

   35]. 
   Gasteruption lianae (Gasteruptionidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, Host not given,
   p. 37]. 
   Gasteruption loiaconoae (Gasteruptionidae): [Sp nov, Argentina, Host not
   given, p. 39].

DT Article
TI The Mystery of Pieris orientis Oberthur, 1880.
AU Tadokoro, Teruo
SO Butterflies (Teinopalpus)
VL 58
PS 34-40
PD September 15 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Since Eitschberger (1984) reviewed Pieris napi-bryoniae complex, Pieris
   orientis has been considered in Europe as an independent species
   occurring in N. E. China, Amur-Ussuri and Korean peninsula. However, my
   recent investigation in these areas and subsequent phylogenic analyses
   didn't show any sign of the presence for orientis. This report
   introduces the process that I have reached to the conclusion that the
   real status of orientis is a synonym of Pieris melete melete.
C1 Tadokoro, Teruo; 7-5-35 Kinuta, Setagaya-Ku, Tokyo 157-0073, Japan,
   Japan.

   Eurasia

   Papilionoidea, Pieridae

   1880, p. 40].

DT Article
TI THE ISOPERLA OF CALIFORNIA (PLECOPTERA: PERLODIDAE); LARVAL DESCRIPTIONS
   AND A KEY TO 17 WESTERN NEARCTIC SPECIES.
AU Sandberg, John B. (jsandberg@csuchico.edu) 
SO Illiesia
VL 7
IS 22
PS 202-258
PD 15 September 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www2.pms-lj.si/illiesia/papers/Illiesia07-22.pdf
AW http://www2.pms-lj.si/illiesia/papers/Illiesia07-22.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The male larvae of 17 western Nearctic species of the stonefly genus
   Isoperla Banks from California, Oregon, and Colorado were reared and
   confirmed studying everted male aedeagi. New maxilla characters are
   described for male larvae and used as primary characters in a larval
   species key. The larvae of two species, I. fulva Claassen and I.
   roguensis Szczytko & Stewart could not be separated and two species not
   currently known to occur in California, I. muir Szczytko & Stewart and
   I. tilasqua Szczytko & Stewart were included in the descriptions and
   key. Isoperla karuk Baumann & Lee is placed as a synonym of I. roguensis
   Szczytko & Stewart, and the larva of I. baumanni Szczytko & Stewart is
   correctly associated for the first time with the previously published
   description of I. bifurcata Szczytko & Stewart.
C1 Sandberg, John B.; Aquatic Bioassessment Lab - California Dept. of Fish
   & Game & CSUC Research Foundation, California State University, Chico,
   CA 95929-0555, USA, USA.

DT Article
TI A taxonomic review of the Night Frog genus Nyctibatrachus Boulenger,
   1882 in the Western Ghats, India (Anura: Nyctibatrachidae) with
   description of twelve new species.
AU Biju, S.D.
   van Bocxlaer, Ines
   Mahony, Stephen
   Dinesh, K.P.
   Radhakrishnan, C.
   Zachariah, Anil
   Giri, Varad
   Bossuyt, Franky
SO Zootaxa
VL 3029
PS 1-96
PD 15 Sep 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03029p096.pdf
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03029p096.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A taxonomic revision of the genus Nyctibatrachus is presented. As a
   result, we recognize 27 species, 12 of which are new to science and
   described herein. Three 'lost' species[long dash]Nyctibatrachus
   sanctipalustris, Nyctibatrachus sylvaticus and Nan- nobatrachus
   kempholeyensis are rediscovered after their original descriptions and
   the latter two species are neotypified. Four species are lectotypified
   (Nannobatrachus beddomii, Nyctibatrachus deccanensis, Nyctibatrachus
   major and Nycti- batrachus sanctipalustris). The taxonomic revision and
   description of new species is based on new morphological, behav- ioural,
   ecological and molecular data from available type specimens and/or
   recent collections from throughout the distribution range of
   Nyctibatrachus. Specimens from the type localities of all previously
   described species were collected and discussed along with the type
   specimens. Nyctibatrachus sholai is considered a junior subjective
   synonym of N. dec- canensis. Nyctibatrachus sanctipalustris modestus is
   resurrected from synonymy, but allocated to the genus Fejervarya. A new
   gland, the subocular gland is introduced to anuran morphological
   terminology. Both the courtship behaviour and ovipositional sites of
   four species are described for the first time. The process of
   fertilisation was carried out in the absence of physical contact between
   males and females in all four species. Furthermore, previously
   unreported parental care be- haviour is documented for the genus,
   including biparental egg attendance (probably clutch hydration) and egg
   guarding (active predator defense). A brief outline of tadpole
   development from egg to metamorph is provided for Nyctibatrachus
   aliciae, with figures of the major developmental stages.
C1 Biju, S.D.; Systematics Lab, Department of Environmental Biology,
   University of Delhi, Delhi 110 007, India, India.
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Reproductive Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Description;
   Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Integument;
   Reproduction; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; India

   morphological character; systematics] [Reproductive behaviour /  / ]
   [India / Western Ghats / distribution].

DT Article
TI A new carnivorous cynodont (Synapsida, Therapsida) from the Brazilian
   Middle Triassic (Santa Maria Formation): Candelariodon barberenai gen.
   et sp. nov.
AU de Oliveira, Teo Veiga (teovoli@yahoo.com.br) 
   Schultz, Cesar Leandro
   Soares, Marina Bento
   Rodrigues, Carlos Nunes
SO Zootaxa
VL 3027
PS 19-28
PD 15 Sep 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3027.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03027p028.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB A new small cynodont, Candelariodon barberenai gen. et sp. nov., from
   the Middle Triassic of Brazil (Santa Maria Formation) is reported. The
   new taxon is represented by a partial mandible having some complete
   teeth. The morphology of the dentary and splenial is similar to other
   carnivorous cynodonts, except for the absence of the angular process of
   the dentary. The anterior-most lower teeth are slightly expanded
   buccolingually with a tall and posteriorly curved main cusp and one or
   two accessory cusps. The posterior-most preserved lower postcanine,
   however, has lingual and buccal rows of cusps, each formed by four
   anteroposteriorly aligned cusps, separated by a shallow basin. This
   tooth resembles the posterior- most lower teeth of Aleodon Crompton 1955
   from the Middle Triassic of Tanzania, but the anterior-most teeth of
   Candelariodon and Aleodon are essentially different. In this context,
   the phylogenetic relationships of the new taxon remain unclear until the
   discovery of more informative material.
C1 de Oliveira, Teo Veiga; Universidade Estadual de Feira de Santana,
   Departamento de Ciencias Biologicas, Avenida Transnordestina, S/N,
   Bairro Novo Horizonte, CEP 44036-900, Feira de Santana, BA, Brazil,
   Brazil.
EM teovoli@yahoo.com.br
SC Paleontology; Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Candelariodon [Triassic /  / New genus]. 
   Candelariodon barberenai [Brazil /  / new species] [Triassic /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Synapsida, Therapsida
OR Candelariodon (Therapsida): [Gen nov, Of Eucynodontia, Type species
   Candelariodon barberenai, p. 22, Triassic; Fossil]. 
   Candelariodon barberenai (Therapsida): [Sp nov, Brazil, Triassic, P. 23;
   Fossil].

DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14712081966
DT Article
TI Two new frog species (Microhylidae: Cophixalus) from boulder habitats on
   Cape York Peninsula, north-east Australia.
AU Hoskin, Conrad J. (conrad.hoskin@gmail.com) 
   Aland, Kieran
SO Zootaxa
VL 3027
PS 39-51
PD 15 Sep 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3027.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/f/zt03027p051.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Australia has a highly localised but diverse radiation of microhylid
   frogs. 18 species are described from north-east Queensland (14
   Cophixalus and 4 Austrochaperina), most with highly localised montane
   distributions. While most species are small (10-25 mm) rainforest
   species, two differ dramatically in ecology and morphology. Cophixalus
   saxatilis and C. zweifeli inhabit isolated areas of jumbled boulder-pile
   habitat and are considerably larger than all other species (30-45 mm).
   Here we describe two new species of large, boulder dwelling Cophixalus
   from the Pascoe River region of Cape York Peninsula. Cophixalus kulakula
   sp. nov. occurs in piled boulder habitat amongst rainforest in the Tozer
   Range area, while Cophixalus pakayakulangun sp. nov. occurs in similar
   habitat in the Kennedy Hills region north of the Pascoe River. These are
   the most northerly sites for Cophixalus in Australia and both occur in
   rainforest areas not occupied by other species of Cophixalus. Both
   species are large (snout-vent length > 40 mm) and of similar morphology
   to the other two boulder-dwelling species. Cophixalus kulakula sp. nov.
   and C. pakayakulangun sp. nov. differ from each other and from all other
   described Cophixalus genetically and in aspects of colour pattern and
   morphology. The call of C. kulakula sp. nov. is also unique, but the
   call of C. pakayakulangun sp. nov. remains unknown. The two new species
   are each others closest relatives (albeit with approximately 8% genetic
   divergence for 12S and 16S mtDNA) and are allied to C. ornatus. The diet
   of both species consists primarily of ants. Both species have highly
   localised distributions but are abundant within these and are probably
   secure.
C1 Hoskin, Conrad J.; School of Marine & Tropical Biology, James Cook
   University, Townsville, Queensland 4811, Australia, Australia.
EM conrad.hoskin@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Australasian region;
   Australasia; Australia
DE Cophixalus kulakula; Cophixalus pakayakulangun [Queensland /  / New
   species]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura,
   Microhylidae
OR Cophixalus kulakula (Microhylidae): [Sp nov, Queensland, P. 42]. 
   Cophixalus pakayakulangun (Microhylidae): [Sp nov, Queensland, P. 46]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14712081966
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14712081967
DT Article
TI A new sponge-inhabiting leptostracan species of the genus Nebalia
   (Crustacea: Phyllocarida: Leptostraca) from the Veracruz Coral Reef
   System, Gulf of Mexico.
AU Ortiz, Manuel
   Winfield, Ignacio (ignacioc@servidor.unam.mx) 
   Chazaro-Olvera, Sergio
SO Zootaxa
VL 3027
PS 52-62
PD 15 Sep 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3027.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03027p062.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB A new species of Leptostraca, Nebalia villalobosi, is described from the
   Veracruz Coral Reef System, SW Gulf of Mexico. The new species was found
   associated with the sponge Ircinia fistularis (Demospongiae) from the
   Blanquilla reef at a depth of 12 m. It differs from the closely related
   species N. longicornis and N. lagartensis in the form of the eyes and
   rostrum, the number of articles in the antennular and antennal flagella,
   the inner border of article 3 on the mandible palp, the length of the
   exopod of maxilla 2, the rounded denticles on pleonite 6, the enlarged
   tip on pleopod 5, and the caudal furcae being slightly longer than the
   telson and pleonite 7 combined. This is the first record of a
   leptostracan associated with the sponge Ircinia fistularis.
C1 Winfield, Ignacio; Laboratorio de Crustaceos, Facultad de Estudios
   Superiores Iztacala-Universidad Nacional Autonoma de Mexico, Av. de los
   Barrios 1, Los Reyes Iztacala, Tlalnepantla, Estado de Mexico, Mexico.
EM ignacioc@servidor.unam.mx

DT Article
TI A new vermiform sea anemone (Anthozoa: Actiniaria) from Argentina:
   Harenactis argentina sp. nov.
AU Lauretta, Daniel (dlauretta@gmail.com) 
   Rodriguez, Estefania
   Penchaszadeh, Pablo E.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3027
PS 9-18
PD 15 Sep 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3027.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03027p018.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB During 2007, 2008, and 2010, 23 specimens of an undescribed vermiform
   sea anemone were collected on Punta Pardelas and Fracaso Beach (Pennsula
   Valdes, Argentina). The specimens have longitudinal rows of cinclides
   distally, all mesenteries perfect, tentacles hexamerously arranged
   without acrospheres, column not divisible into regions, no marginal
   sphincter and no conchula. We describe these specimens as a new species
   within the genus Harenactis (family Haloclavidae). Harenactis argentina
   sp. nov. is the second species of Harenactis; it represents the first
   record of this genus in the southern hemisphere and the first record of
   a soft bottom-dwelling sea anemone in the Argentine continental zone.
   Furthermore, we discuss the familial placement and relationships of the
   genus Harenactis and other athenarian sea anemones.
C1 Lauretta, Daniel; Museo Argentino de Ciencias Naturales "Bernardino
   Rivadavia" [long dash] CONICET, Av. Angel Gallardo 470, Buenos Aires,
   Argentina, Argentina.
EM dlauretta@gmail.com
OI Penchaszadeh, Pablo E/0000-0002-2043-8814
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Marine zones; Atlantic
   Ocean
DE Harenactis argentina [South Atlantic / Argentina / New species]. 
TN Coelenterates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Cnidaria, Anthozoa, Zoantharia, Actiniaria
OR Harenactis - Torrey 1902 (Actiniaria): [Emended diagnosis, P. 11]. 
   Harenactis argentina (Actiniaria): [Sp nov, Argentina (marine), P. 11].

TI Quill mites (Acari: Syringophilidae) from mimid birds (Aves: Mimidae).

U2 5
AB Two new species of syringophilid mites parasitizing birds from the
   family Mimidae are described: Syringophilopsis mimidus sp. nov. ex
   Margarops fuscatus (Vieillot) from Central America and Rafapicobia
   toxostoma sp. nov. ex Toxostoma curvirostre (Swainson) from USA.
   Additionally, Torotrogla mima Kethley, 1970 is redescribed based on the
   material ex Mimus triurus (Vieillot) from Argentina and M. patagonicus
   (Lafresnaye and Orbigny) from South Africa.

DT Article
TI Gastropoda (Mollusca) from the Rockall and Hatton Banks, northeastern
   Atlantic Ocean. 3.
AU Hoffman, L. (hoffmanl@xs4all.nl) 
   van Heugten, B.
   Lavaleye, M.S.S.
SO Miscellanea Malacologica
VL 5
IS 2
PS 23-52
PD 14 September 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A record is given on the occurrence and abundance of 40 gastropod
   species in the subclass Caenogastropoda that have been collected during
   the NIOZ expeditions (2004-2008) to the Rockall and Hatton Banks. The
   families Cerithiopsidae, Epitoniidae and Eulimidae are particularly well
   represented with respectively 7, 7 and 17 species. Curveulima styla n.
   sp. has been described as a new species in Eulimidae. Many species
   should be considered as rare and some of them have never been recorded
   in this part of the Atlantic Ocean. Examples of 'rare' species that are
   encountered in the Rockall-Hatton area include Melanella gagei
   Bouchet&Waren, 1986, Batheulima fuscoapicata (Jeffreys, 1884),
   Fusceulima projectilabrum Bouchet&Waren, 1986, Eulitoma arcus
   Bouchet&Waren, 1986, Curveulima cabiochi Bouchet&Waren, 1986, Iphitus
   tuberatus Jeffreys, 1883, Gregorioiscala sarsi (Kobelt, 1905),
   Papuliscala cerithielloides Bouchet&Waren, 1986, and Teinostoma azoricum
   (Dautzenberg&H. Fischer, 1896).

EM hoffmanl@xs4all.nl

DT Article
TI Buthus awashensis sp. n. from Ethiopia (Scorpiones: Buthidae).
AU Kovarik, Frantisek (kovarik.scorpio@gmail.com) 
SO Euscorpius
VL 128
PS 1-6
PD 14 September 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.science.marshall.edu/fet/euscorpius/p2011_128.pdf
AW http://www.science.marshall.edu/fet/euscorpius/p2011_128.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Buthus awashensis sp. n. from the Awash region of Ethiopia, is described
   and compared with B. berberensis Pocock, 1900 from Somaliland. The new
   species is characterized chiefly by the total length of 50[long dash]65
   mm. B. berberensis reaches only 45[long dash]55 mm and differs in
   coloration, with adults having the chela of pedipalp and chelicerae
   entirely yellow without dark reticulations, and by mophometric
   characters, mainly the shape of the chela of pedipalp. Pectinal marginal
   tips extend the to proximal end of the fourth sternite in males of B.
   awashensis sp. n. and to proximal end of the fifth sternite in males of
   B. berberensis. Included are color photos of both sexes of dead and
   alive B. awashensis sp. n. and B. berberensis and of their localities.
C1 Kovarik, Frantisek; P.O. Box 27, CZ-145 01 Praha 45, Czech Republic,
   Czech Republic.
EM kovarik.scorpio@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1536-9307

   Africa

PT J
AN ZOOR14712081959
DT Article
TI Molecular and morphological evidence for short range endemism in the
   Kinnecaris solitaria complex (Copepoda: Parastenocarididae), with
   descriptions of seven new species.
AU Karanovic, Tomislav (Tomislav.Karanovic@utas.edu.au) 
   Cooper, Steven J.B.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3026
PS 1-64
PD 14 Sep 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/f/zt03026p064.pdf
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/f/zt03026p064.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Recent investigation of one of the larger calcretes in the uppermost
   reaches of the Carey palaeochannel in the Yilgarn region of Western
   Australia revealed an unprecedented diversity of copepod crustaceans.
   Twenty-two different species and subspecies, from six copepod families,
   represent 70% of the previously recorded copepod a-diversity in the
   whole region, although the area investigated is less than 3% of its
   surface. The aims of this study were to explore the diversity of the
   harpacticoid genus Kinnecaris Jakobi, 1972 using both molecular and
   morphological methods, establish precise species boundaries, find their
   accurate area of distribution, reconstruct phylogenetic relationships,
   and explore colonisation pathways. To achieve this we sampled very
   intensively in the area, as well as in two neighbouring palaeochannels,
   analysing more than 700 samples from 230 different localities, half of
   which contained copepods. Seven species are described here as new, five
   of them from the Yeelirrie palaeochannel (K. esbe sp. nov., K. lined sp.
   nov., K. linel sp. nov., K. linesae sp. nov., and K. uranusi sp. nov.)
   and one each from two neighbouring palaeochannels (K. barrambie sp. nov.
   and K. lakewayi sp. nov.). Parastenocaris jane Karanovic, 2006 from the
   Pilbara region, along with a newly described third Australian
   parastenocaridid genus from the Yilgarn, were used as outgroups in our
   molecular analysis. The COI fragment was successfully PCR-amplified from
   12 parastenocaridid specimens using a nested combination of primers. All
   analyses supported the presence of at least seven genetically divergent
   lineages, most supported with very high bootstrap values. Three genera
   formed three separate clades, and the average pairwise distances between
   Kinnecaris morpho-taxa were found to be very high (8.2-16.8 %), while
   the highest divergences within morpho-taxa were 0.3%. Some conflict
   between molecular phylogenies and morphological data was observed when
   it came to recognizing different groups of species. While morphology
   indicates that K. esbe, K. linel, and K. uranusi represent a group of
   very closely related species, supported by a number of synapomorphies,
   molecular analyses suggest that K. linel and K. uranusi are only
   remotely related. We argue in favor of morphological data, until more
   markers can be studied to try to resolve these differences. In
   Yeelirrie, morphological evidence would suggest a downstream
   colonisation history in the genus Kinnecaris, where the most
   plesiomorphic form (K. linesae) lives in the uppermost reaches of the
   palaeochannel, and the trend in the caudal rami elongation and denser
   somite ornamentation is obvious downstream the palaeochannel (K.
   uranusi, K. linel, and then K. esbe), with the only exception being K.
   lined, which probably represents an independent colonisation event.
   Parastenocarids are copepods of freshwater origin, and we argure that
   they can probably disperse downstream during periods of increased
   rainfall, evolving into separate species in isolated calcrete pockets
   during periods of increased aridity. Although some of the questions
   remained unanswered in this study, detailed morphological and molecular
   observations indicate that we are not dealing with one widely
   distributed and variable species in the Yilgarn region, but rather with
   a complex of short range endemics. Areas of distribution for different
   species range from 30 km to less than 5 km in diameter. Very strong
   seasonal dynamics in this subterranean community was observed, and this
   is a novel concept for these ecosystems globally. A key to nine
   Australian species of Kinnecaris is also included.
C1 Karanovic, Tomislav; Institute for Marine and Antarctic Studies,
   University of Tasmania, Private Bag 129, Hobart, TAS 7001, Australia,
   Australia.
EM Tomislav.Karanovic@utas.edu.au
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Biometrics; General
   morphology; Genetics; Evolution; Variation; Zoogeography; Land zones;
   Australasian region; Australasia; Australia
DE Kinnecaris [Australia /  / Key to species]. 
   Kinnecaris barrambie; Kinnecaris esbe; Kinnecaris lakewayi; Kinnecaris
   lined; Kinnecaris linel; Kinnecaris linesae; Kinnecaris uranusi [Western
   Australia /  / New species]. 
   Kinnecaris solitaria complex [Biometrics / Morphometric variation /
   systematics] [General morphology /  / ] [Molecular genetics / Molecular
   diversity / ] [Phylogeny / Phylogeographic analysis / ] [Biochemical
   variation /  / ] [Morphological variation /  / ] [Zoogeography /  / ]
   [Western Australia / Yilgarn region, Carey palaeochannel / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Copepoda, Harpacticoida
OR Kinnecaris - Jakobi 1972 (Harpacticoida): [Key to species, Australia, P.
   60]. 
   Kinnecaris barrambie (Harpacticoida): [Sp nov, Western Australia, P.
   19]. 
   Kinnecaris esbe (Harpacticoida): [Sp nov, Western Australia, P. 23]. 
   Kinnecaris lakewayi (Harpacticoida): [Sp nov, Western Australia, P. 10].
   
   Kinnecaris lined (Harpacticoida): [Sp nov, Western Australia, P. 42]. 
   Kinnecaris linel (Harpacticoida): [Sp nov, Western Australia, P. 29]. 
   Kinnecaris linesae (Harpacticoida): [Sp nov, Western Australia, P. 46]. 
   Kinnecaris solitaria complex (Harpacticoida). 
   Kinnecaris uranusi (Harpacticoida): [Sp nov, Western Australia, P. 37]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14712081959
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR14712081956
DT Article
TI A new species of Abacarus (Acari: Prostigmata: Eriophyidae) damaging
   sugarcane, Sacharrum officinarum L., from Costa Rica - the first
   eriophyoid mite described with a tibial seta on leg II.
AU Navia, Denise (navia@cenargen.embrapa.br) 
   Flechtmann, Carlos H.W.
   Lindquist, Evert E.
   Aguilar, Hugo
SO Zootaxa
VL 3025
PS 51-58
PD 14 Sep 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3025.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03025p058.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of eriophyoid mite, belonging in the genus Abacarus Keifer
   (Eriophyidae), causing damage to sugarcane, Saccharum officinarum L.
   (Poaceae), in Costa Rica is illustrated and described. Abacarus doctus
   n. sp. is the only eriophyoid species recorded so far with a tibial seta
   (IE) on the second pair of legs, an unexpected characteristic observed
   for the first time in the superfamily Eriophyoidea. Remarks on the
   phylogenetic and taxonomical aspects related to the presence of this
   seta are presented. Damage symptoms caused by this mite are presented as
   well as a key for Abacarus species described from sugarcane. In
   addition, the need to apply biosecurity procedures during sugarcane
   germplasm exchange to avoid dissemination of the new mite species is
   discussed.
C1 Navia, Denise; Laboratorio de Quarentena Vegetal, EMBRAPA Recursos
   Geneticos e Biotecnologia, C. Postal 02372, 70.770-900 Brasilia, DF,
   Brazil, Brazil.
EM navia@cenargen.embrapa.br
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; Central America
DE Abacarus doctus [Costa Rica /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari

   sugarcane, p. 57]. 
   Abacarus doctus - Navia & Flechtmann 2011 (Acari): [Sp nov, Costa Rica,
   P. 52].

DT Article
TI Nyctobadistes gen. nov. (Isopoda: Asellota: Munnopsidae), a new genus
   from Tasmanian waters, Australia, with the description of a new species.
AU Merrin, Kelly L. (kellymerrin@hotmail.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3025
PS 59-65
PD 14 Sep 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3025.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03025p065.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus and new species of Munnopsidae Lilljeborg, 1864 is
   described. Nyctobadistes gen. nov. is represented by a single species,
   Nyctobadistes hamatus sp. nov. and was collected from off Tasmania,
   south-eastern Australia. Nyctobadistes gen. nov. is similar to
   Bathybadistes Hessler and Thistle, 1975, however, it can be
   distinguished from this genus by the combination of: the lack of apical
   setae on the dorsal body spines; the lack of lateral extensions on the
   natasomal pereonites; the slender carpus of at least pereopod 6; and the
   anterolateral margins of the pleon lack a spine and apical seta.
C1 Merrin, Kelly L.; 9 Haering Rd, Boronia, 3155, Victoria, Australia,
   Australia.

   Centrurus granosus simplex Thorell, 1876 (Scorpiones: Buthidae).
AU de Armas, Luis F. (dearmas@ecologia.cu) 
   Teruel, Rolando
   Kovarik, Frantisek
SO Euscorpius
VL 127
PS 1-11
PD 13 September 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.science.marshall.edu/fet/euscorpius/p2011_127.pdf
AW http://www.science.marshall.edu/fet/euscorpius/p2011_127.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Centruroides granosus (Thorell, 1876) is redescribed based on several
   specimens of both sexes from Panama. We demonstrate that the original
   description of this species was based on an immature (subadult) male,
   which is herein designated as the lectotype. We conclude that Centrurus
   granosus simplex Thorell, 1876 is a senior synonym of Centruroides
   testaceus arubensis (Bakker, 1963), and elevate it to species level:
   Centruroides simplex (Thorell, 1876), comb. nov.

   Province, 32500, Cuba, Cuba.

PT J
AN ZOOR14712081711
DT Article
TI Specific limits and emerging diversity patterns in East African
   populations of laminate-toothed rats, genus Otomys (Muridae: Murinae:
   Otomyini): Revision of the Otomys typus complex.
AU Taylor, Peter J. (Peter.Taylor@univen.ac.za) 
   Lavrenchenko, Leonid A.
   Carleton, Michael D.
   Verheyen, Erik
   Bennett, Nigel C.
   Oosthuizen, Carel J.
   Maree, Sarita
SO Zootaxa
VL 3024
PS 1-66
PD 13 Sep 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03024p066.pdf
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03024p066.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB We combined evidence from biogeography, craniodental traits, linear and
   geometric morphometrics (233 skulls), cytogenetics (karyotypes of 18
   individuals) and mitochondrial DNA sequences (44 cytochrome b and 21 12S
   rRNA sequences) to test species limits within Otomys typus s.l.
   (Muridae: Murinae: Otomyini), a complex that is patchily distributed
   across alpine zones of Ethiopia and East Africa. Our results confirm the
   specific validity of O. dartmouthi, O. jacksoni, O. orestes, and O.
   uzungwensis, forms recently removed from synonymy under typus s.l.;
   support elevation of four other alpine forms to species (O. fortior, O.
   helleri, O. thomasi, and O. zinki); identify three additional new
   species (O. cheesmani sp. nov., O. simiensis sp. nov., O. yaldeni sp.
   nov.); and enable redefinition of O. typus s.s. as a species restricted
   to certain mountains west of the Great Rift Valley in Ethiopia (Simien
   and Guna Mountains in the north, extending to the highlands of the
   western rim of the Rift Valley). Phylogenetic interpretation of the
   cytochrome b data clearly demonstrates that the alpine morphotype once
   united under O. typus s.l. has originated independently at high
   elevations on several mountain ranges in eastern and northeastern
   Africa; although generally adapted to high-elevation vegetation, such
   alpine species are ecologically segregated from one another. Patterns of
   morphometric, genetic, and ecological differentiation among populations
   once misassigned to nominal O. tropicalis and O. typus more
   parsimoniously reflect regional cladogenesis along elevational
   gradients, rather than multiple, successive colonization by different
   ancestral forms from southern Africa as earlier supposed. Although
   incomplete and preliminary, information gathered for O. tropicalis
   indicates that it too is a species composite; several lines of research
   are discussed to redress its polyphyletic content. Our results, together
   with other recent taxonomic studies of Otomys, appreciably elevate the
   level of endemism within eastern Africa and underscore the significance
   of Africa's eastern highlands to the continental diversification of
   Otomyini.
C1 Taylor, Peter J.; Department of Ecology & Resource Management,
   University of Venda, Private Bag X5050, Thohoyandou, 0950, South Africa,
   South Africa.
EM Peter.Taylor@univen.ac.za
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Status; Biometrics;
   Skeletal and supporting structures; Skeleton; Genetics; Cytogenetics;
   Chromosomes; Evolution; Zoogeography; Land zones; Afrotropical region;
   Africa
DE Otomys cheesmani; Otomys simiensis; Otomys yaldeni [Ethiopia /  / New
   species]. 
   Otomys typus complex [Biometrics / Skull morphometrics / systematics]
   [Skull /  / ] [Karyotype /  / ] [Molecular genetics / mtDNA sequences /
   ] [Phylogeny / Cladistics / ] [Zoogeography /  / ] [Africa / East Africa
   / distribution]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Rodents; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Rodentia, Muridae
OR Otomys cheesmani (Muridae): [Sp nov, Ethiopia, P. 43]. 
   Otomys helleri - Frick 1914 (Muridae): [Raised from, Otomys typus
   helleri, p. 45]. 
   Otomys simiensis (Muridae): [Sp nov, Ethiopia, P. 47]. 
   Otomys typus complex (Muridae): [Revision, P. 43]. 
   Otomys typus helleri - Frick 1914 (Muridae): [Raised to, Otomys helleri,
   p. 45]. 
   Otomys yaldeni (Muridae): [Sp nov, Ethiopia, P. 52].

DT Article
TI A new European species of Drymeia Meigen (Diptera: Muscidae) near D.
   brumalis (Rondani), with observations of a unique prestomal teeth
   structure.
AU Michelsen, Verner (vmichelsen@snm.ku.dk) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3023
PS 51-60
PD 13 Sep 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3023.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt03023p060.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of Drymeia Meigen, D. pyrenaea sp. nov. is described and
   distinguished from the very similar D. brumalis (Rondani) based on
   material from northern Spain and Portugal. It is argued that records of
   D. brumalis and possibly even D. alpicola (Rondani) from outside Europe
   are probably based on misidentifications. A previously unnoticed, unique
   prestomal teeth structure is reported from several species of Drymeia.
   Preliminary observations show a remarkable diversity in prestomal teeth
   structure among species of Drymeia. This is documented by images of flat
   mounted labella.
C1 Michelsen, Verner; Natural History Museum of Denmark, University of
   Copenhagen, Universitetsparken 15, DK-2100 Copenhagen O, Denmark,
   Denmark.

   Appendages; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe

DT Article
TI Two new species of Cnemidophorus (Squamata: Teiidae) of the C. ocellifer
   group, from Bahia, Brazil.
AU Arias, Federico (fjarias@unsa.edu.ar) 
   de Carvalho, Celso Morato
   Rodrigues, Miguel Trefaut
   Zaher, Hussam
SO Zootaxa
VL 3022
PS 1-21
PD 12 Sep 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3022.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03022p021.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Two new species of Cnemidophorus are described from the right bank of
   the Sao Francisco river, in the northwestern part of state of Bahia,
   Brazil. Both species are assigned to the Cnemidophorus ocellifer group
   and are distinguished from all other congeners on the basis of lepidosis
   and color pattern. One of them, Cnemidophorus cyanurus, shares with the
   species of the subgroup of C. littoralis (C. abaetensis, C. littoralis
   and C. venetacaudus), a bluish green tail, spurs on the heels of males,
   6[long dash]7 supraciliaries, a high number of femoral pores (27[long
   dash]45), a row of enlarged scales in the dorsal part of the humerus,
   and 8 to 10 rows of ventral scales. The second species, Cnemidophorus
   nigrigula, shares with the C. ocellifer subgroup (composed of C.
   ocellifer, C. mumbuca, C. jalapensis and C. confusionibus) a low number
   of femoral pores (14[long dash] 21), enlarged scales in the temporal
   region posterior to the third subocular, 5 supraciliaries, 6 to 8 rows
   of ventral scales, and a brown tail color. It is also characterized by
   males being conspicuously larger than females and by females retaining
   the juvenile color pattern, which is lost in adult males. The latter
   characteristic has not been reported in any species of the C. ocellifer
   group before now. The two new species occur sympatrically at Santo
   Inacio.
C1 Arias, Federico; CONICET- IBIGEO, Facultad de Ciencias Naturales,
   Universidad Nacional de Salta, Av. Bolivia 5150, CP- 4400, Salta,
   Argentina, Argentina.
EM fjarias@unsa.edu.ar
RI Zaher, Hussam/D-4000-2012
OI Zaher, Hussam/0000-0002-6994-489X
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Cnemidophorus cyanurus; Cnemidophorus nigrigula [Brazil /  / New
   species]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Teiidae
OR Cnemidophorus cyanurus (Teiidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 9]. 
   Cnemidophorus nigrigula (Teiidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 3]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14711080853
DA 2020-09-17

TI Description of Dorylaimoides alborzicus sp. n. (Dorylaimida: Nematoda)
   from Iran, with updated compendium and key to the species of
   Dorylaimoides.
AU Pedram, Majid
   Pourjam, Ebrahim (pourjame@modares.ac.ir) 
   Vinciguerra, Maria T.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3022
PS 58-68
PD 12 Sep 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3022.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03022p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Dorylaimoides alborzicus sp. n. is described. Characteristics of the new
   species include a lip region separated from the rest of body by a sharp
   constriction, 1.1.1.3 mm long body, 10.11 [mu]m long odontostyle dorsal
   line and 8.10 [mu]m long odontostyle ventral line, 15.16 [mu]m long
   arcuate odontophore, anterior uterine sac 37.61 [mu]m long (1.1.1.7
   times corresponding body width), female tail straight to ventrally bent,
   elongate conoid with rounded terminus and 46.62 [mu]m long and males
   with 31.35 [mu]m long spicules, 5.6 ventromedian supplements and
   ventrally bent tail, 39.60 [mu]m long. An updated identification key to
   all the valid species of Dorylaimoides, as well as a table of data for
   the species not included in the study by Pena Santiago and Peralta
   (1997b) is given.

TI A taxonomic revision of Tridrepana Swinhoe, 1895 in China, with
   descriptions of three new species (Lepidoptera, Drepanidae).
AU Song, Wenhui
   Xue, Dayong
   Han, Hongxiang (hanhx@ioz.ac.cn) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3021
PS 39-62
PD 12 Sep 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3021.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt03021p062.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The genus Tridrepana Swinhoe in China is reviewed, nineteen species are
   recognized, of which, three new species T. subadelpha sp. nov., T.
   bicuspidata sp. nov. and T. subunispina sp. nov. from Yunnan and Hainan
   are described; two new synonyms are introduced: T. leva Chu & Wang,
   1988. syn. n. (= T. crocea (Leech, 1888)) and T. flava sinica Chu &
   Wang, 1988. syn. n. (= T. flava flava (Moore, 1879)); T. emina is sunk
   to be a subspecies of T. arikana; T. argentistriga Warren, 1896 and T.
   rubromarginata indica Watson, 1957 are recorded in China for the first
   time. Descriptions for the genus and new species, a key and diagnoses
   for the Chinese species are provided. Illustrations of the external
   features and the genitalia are presented.

DT Article
TI Systematics of the genus Soesilarishius (Araneae: Salticidae:
   Euophryinae).
AU Sanches Ruiz, Gustavo Rodrigo (gustavoruiz86@hotmail.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3022
PS 22-38
PD 12 Sep 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3022.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03022p038.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Soesilarishius Makhan, 2007 is revised: a diagnosis and a
   redescription are proposed based on the type species, seven new species
   from northeastern Brazil and Soesilarishius aurifrons (Taczanowski,
   1878) comb. nov. from Peru. The previously monotypic genus contains now
   9 species and is characterized by the reduced spiraled embolus. The
   species S. minimus sp. nov., S. lunatus sp. nov., S. cymbialis sp. nov.
   and S. dromedarius sp. nov. are described based on specimens from the
   State of Pernambuco, while S. crispiventer sp. nov., S. spinipes sp.
   nov. and S. albipes sp. nov. are based on specimens from the State of
   Bahia. In addition, the type series of Euophrys aurifrons Taczanowski,
   1878 from Peru is revised, a lectotype is designated and the male palp
   is illustrated for the first time.
C1 Sanches Ruiz, Gustavo Rodrigo; Instituto de Ciencias Biologicas,
   Universidade Federal do Para, Rua Augusto Corraa, 01, Guama, CEP
   66075-110, Belem, Para, Brazil, Brazil.

PT J
AN ZOOR14711080858
DT Article
TI A new leaf tailed gecko species from northern Madagascar with a
   preliminary assessment of molecular and morphological variability in the
   Uroplatus ebenaui group.
AU Ratsoavana, Fanomezana Mihaja (noufam@yahoo.fr) 
   Louis, Edward E., Jr
   Crottini, Angelica
   Randrianiaina, Roger-Daniel
   Glaw, Frank
   Vences, Miguel
SO Zootaxa
VL 3022
PS 39-57
PD 12 Sep 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3022.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03022p057.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Endemic to Madagascar, the genus Uroplatus of the family Gekkonidae
   consists of 13 nominal species of leaf-tailed geckos. These forest
   dwelling lizards are famous for their cryptic and odd appearance. We
   describe a new species of the Uroplatus ebenaui group from the Montagne
   d'Ambre massif in northern Madagascar. Uroplatus finiavana sp. nov., is
   morphologically similar to the sympatric U. ebenaui but differs in
   multiple character state expressions, among which are a longer tail and
   an unpigmentated oral mucosa. It also can be differentiated from U.
   ebenaui and all other Uroplatus species based on a high level of
   divergence in the mitochondrial ND4 gene and the nuclear C-mos gene, and
   no instances of haplotype sharing exist in these genes among the
   analysed species. The new species is relatively abundant at Montagne
   d'Ambre National Park where at lower elevations (ca. 700 m) it occurs
   together with U. ebenaui, without any signal of genetic admixture.
   Records of U. ebenaui in the mountains and forest blocks of northern
   Madagascar (especially in the Tsaratanana massif) actually represent
   other candidate species with distinct morphology and characterized by a
   high genetic divergence from the described species. Beside the
   description of the new species we discuss the geographic provenance of
   the holotypes of the nominal species and synonyms in the U. ebenaui
   group and provide further information on the phylogeny of the U. ebenaui
   species group including the first incorporation of Uroplatus malama in a
   molecular data set.
C1 Ratsoavana, Fanomezana Mihaja; Departement de Biologie Animale,
   Universite d'Antananarivo, BP 906, Antananarivo, 101, Madagascar,
   Madagascar.
EM noufam@yahoo.fr
RI Crottini, Angelica/I-7680-2013
OI Crottini, Angelica/0000-0002-8505-3050; Vences,
   Miguel/0000-0003-0747-0817
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Evolution; Land zones;
   Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Uroplatus ebenaui group [Phylogeny /  / Systematics] [Madagascar /  /
   distribution]. 
   Uroplatus finiavana [Madagascar /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Gekkonidae
OR Uroplatus ebenaui group (Gekkonidae): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, P. 43]. 
   Uroplatus finiavana (Gekkonidae): [Sp nov, Madagascar, P. 47]. 
DI 10.11646/zootaxa.3022.1.3
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14711080858
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI An illustrated key to fruit flies (Diptera: Tephritidae) from Peninsular
   India and the Andaman and Nicobar Islands.
AU David, K.J. (davidento@gmail.com) 
   Ramani, S.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3021
PS 1-31
PD 12 Sep 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3021.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt03021p031.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB An illustrated key and a checklist are provided for 126 species of fruit
   flies under 46 genera in four subfamilies namely Dacinae, Phytalmiinae,
   Tephritinae and Trypetinae. Among these, Acroceratitis striata
   (Froggatt), Rhochmopterum venustum (de Meijere) and Themara yunnana Zia
   are new records for India. Bactrocera yercaudiae Drew is placed as a
   synonymn of Bactrocera digressa Radhakrishnan.

DT Article
TI Review of the genus Truljalia Gorochov (Orthoptera: Gryllidae;
   Podoscirtinae; Podoscirtini) from China.
AU Liu, Hao-Yu
   Shi, Fu-Ming (shifmi@yahoo.com.cn) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3021
PS 32-38
PD 12 Sep 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3021.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt03021p038.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Truljalia Gorochov from China is reviewed. A new species
   (China: Yunnan), Truljalia multiprotubera sp. nov. is described. T.
   prolongata Wang & Woo, 1992 is considered as a junior synonym of T.
   meloda Gorochov, 1992. T. viminea Gorochov, 2002 is recorded to China
   for the first time, but T. hofmanni (Saussure) is excluded from Chinese
   fauna. A distribution map of all Truljalia species is presented.
C1 Shi, Fu-Ming; College of Life Sciences, Hebei University, Baoding
   071002, China, China.
EM shifmi@yahoo.com.cn

PT J
AN ZOOR14803021701
DT Article
TI [Trechus (Trechus) schyberosiae sp. nov., a relict endemic from the
   pre-Alps of northern Switzerland (Coleoptera: Carabidae, Trechini).]
FT Trechus (Trechus) schyberosiae sp. nov., ein Reliktendemit aus den
   Voralpen der noerdlichen Schweiz (Coleoptera: Carabidae, Trechini).
AU Szallies, Alexander (szal@zhaw.ch) 
   Schuele, Peter
SO Contributions to Natural History (Bern)
VL 18
PS 1-10
PD 9 September 2011
PY 2011
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Trechus (Trechus) schyberosiae sp. nov. from the Northwestern Alps of
   Switzerland is described and the new species is assigned to the group of
   Trechus pertyi HEER, 1837. The new species can reliably be separated by
   its male genitalia from the other Trechus species also occurring in the
   Northern Swiss Alps. The most similar species, however, appears to be T.
   longulus DANIEL & DANIEL, 1898 from Northeastern Italy and Slovenia. A
   brief discussion stresses the problem of persistence of restricted
   endemic species such as T. schyberosiae sp. nov. during the glacial
   periods.
C1 Szallies, Alexander; Zuercher Hochschule fuer Angewandte Wissenschaften
   ZHAW, Campus Gruenthal, CH-4056 Waedenswil, Switzerland, Switzerland.
EM szal@zhaw.ch
SC Zoology
SN 1660-9972
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Trechus (Trechus) schyberosiae [Switzerland /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae
OR Trechus (Trechus) schyberosiae (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Switzerland, P. 3].
   
   Trechus pertyi - Heer 1837 (Carabidae): [Diagnostic characters, P. 6]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14803021701

PT J
AN ZOOR14712082843
PM 22013749
DT Article
TI Survey of protozoan, helminth and viral infections in shrimp Litopenaeus
   setiferus and prawn Macrobrachium acanthurus native to the Jamapa River
   region, Mexico.
AU Dominguez-Machin, Magda E.
   Hernandez-Vergara, Martha P.
   Jimenez-Garcia, Isabel
   Sima-Alvarez, Raul
   Rodriguez-Canul, Rossanna (rossana@mda.cinvestav.mx) 
SO Diseases of Aquatic Organisms
VL 96
IS 2
PS 97-103
PD Sep 9 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 24
AB We surveyed protozoan and metazoan parasites as well as white spot
   syndrome virus (WSSV) and infectious hypodermal hematopoietic necrosis
   virus (IHHNV) in white shrimp Litopenaeus setiferus and the palaemonid
   prawn Macrobrachium acanthurus native to the lower Jamapa River region
   of Veracruz, Mexico. The presence of parasites and the infection
   parameters were evaluated in 113 palaemonid prawns collected during the
   northwind (n = 45), rainy (n = 38) and dry seasons (n = 30) between
   October 2007 and July 2008, and in 91 shrimp collected in the rainy
   season between May and June 2008. In L. setiferus, ciliates of the
   subclass Apostomatia (Ascophrys sp.) were evident in gills, and
   third-stage larvae of the nematode Physocephalus sexalatus were evident
   in the stomach. Cestodes of the genus Prochristianella were evident in
   the hepatopancreas, while some gregarines of the genus Nematopsis, as
   well as unidentified larval cestodes, were observed in the intestine.
   Histology identified Ascophrys sp. in association with gill necrosis and
   tissue melanization. Slight inflammation was observed in intestinal
   epithelium near cestode larvae. In M. acanthurus, epibionts of the
   protozoans Epistylis sp., Acineta sp. and Lagenophrys sp. were observed
   under uropods, periopods and pleopods. An unidentified ciliate of the
   Apostomatia was also found in the gills, and Nematopsis was identified
   in the intestine. No histopathology was observed in association with
   these parasites. Moreover, neither WSSV nor IHHNV were detected by the
   polymerase chain reaction (PCR) in any of the L. setiferus or M.
   acanthurus analysed.
C1 Rodriguez-Canul, Rossanna; Lab de Immunologia y Biol Mol, Centro de
   Invest y de Estudios Avanzados del Inst Politec Nac-Unidad Merida,
   Antigua Carretera a Progreso Km, 97310 Merida, Yucatan, Mexico, Mexico.
EM rossana@mda.cinvestav.mx
RI del Pilar Rodriguez-Canul, Rossanna/AAH-1895-2020
OI del Pilar Rodriguez-Canul, Rossanna/0000-0003-0469-1489;
   HERNANDEZ-VERGARA, MARTHA PATRICIA/0000-0002-1589-1913

   Diseases
SN 0177-5103

TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates; Nematodes; Platyhelminths;
